articles.headline: Teachers in Oklahoma and Kentucky Walk Out: ‘It Really Is a Wildfire’
articles.snippet: A wave of walkouts and rallies in red states has been organized largely by ordinary teachers.
articles.abstract: A wave of walkouts and rallies in red states has been organized largely by ordinary teachers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of teachers in Oklahoma and Kentucky walked off the job Monday morning, shutting down school districts as they protested cuts in pay, benefits and school funding in a movement that has spread rapidly since igniting in West Virginia this year.

articles.headline: Russia Presses Trump for White House Meeting With Putin
articles.snippet: The Kremlin said it hoped President Trump would follow through on his proposal for such a session, made before last week’s tit-for-tat expulsion of diplomats.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin said it hoped President Trump would follow through on his proposal for such a session, made before last week’s tit-for-tat expulsion of diplomats.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia sought to move beyond last week’s diplomatic confrontation with the West on Monday by pressing President Trump for a White House meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin that would undercut the perception that the angry reaction to the poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain has left it isolated from the international community.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Markets That Climbed the Trump Bump Are Tumbling Down From It
articles.snippet: The stock market continued to plunge Monday, as investors were unnerved by the unpredictable White House. Stocks are now down 4 percent this year.
articles.abstract: The stock market continued to plunge Monday, as investors were unnerved by the unpredictable White House. Stocks are now down 4 percent this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump Bump is becoming the Trump Slump.

articles.headline: Sermons and Shouted Insults: How Erdogan Keeps Turkey Spellbound
articles.snippet: The Turkish president treats his country to up to three speeches a day, broadcast live on multiple channels, in a divisive style fit for an era of strongmen.
articles.abstract: The Turkish president treats his country to up to three speeches a day, broadcast live on multiple channels, in a divisive style fit for an era of strongmen.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — As President Trump has his tweets, the leader of Turkey has his speeches.

articles.headline: To Trump, It’s the ‘Amazon Washington Post.’ To Its Editor, That’s Baloney.
articles.snippet: The president calls the paper, which is owned by Amazon’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, “a lobbyist weapon,” among other things. “There isn’t anybody here who is paid by Amazon,” the editor, Martin Baron, said.
articles.abstract: The president calls the paper, which is owned by Amazon’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, “a lobbyist weapon,” among other things. “There isn’t anybody here who is paid by Amazon,” the editor, Martin Baron, said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon does not own The Washington Post. President Trump, however — impervious to certain facts and armed with a Twitter account — has tried hard to convince the public otherwise.

articles.headline: Looming China Trade Action Divides Industry and Roils Markets
articles.snippet: Companies are united around the idea of addressing China’s unfair trade practices, but details of the president’s plan have set off fierce opposition.
articles.abstract: Companies are united around the idea of addressing China’s unfair trade practices, but details of the president’s plan have set off fierce opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s promise to take tough action against China’s unfair economic practices was one of his most popular campaign ideas. But as the United States prepares stiff trade measures and China retaliates, stock markets have plummeted and some of America’s biggest companies are pushing back.

articles.headline: Facebook Should Consider a ‘Why Me?’ Button
articles.snippet: The internet giant has plenty of problems to fix. Andrew Ross Sorkin thinks explaining why particular ads are presented to users would be a good start.
articles.abstract: The internet giant has plenty of problems to fix. Andrew Ross Sorkin thinks explaining why particular ads are presented to users would be a good start.
articles.lead_paragraph: “One of our biggest responsibilities is to protect data.”

articles.headline: Jeweler to the Stars Flees as India Seethes Over Bank Fraud
articles.snippet: The search for Nirav Modi captivates a country increasingly frustrated by corruption cases involving state banks that could cost taxpayers dearly.
articles.abstract: The search for Nirav Modi captivates a country increasingly frustrated by corruption cases involving state banks that could cost taxpayers dearly.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nirav Modi brightened Kate Winslet’s earlobes and made Taraji P. Henson’s collarbone glitter.

articles.headline: China Finds California Wine Pairs Well With a Trade War
articles.snippet: Retaliatory tariffs are a blow to exporters increasingly catering to young, newly wealthy Chinese looking for bottles with cachet.
articles.abstract: Retaliatory tariffs are a blow to exporters increasingly catering to young, newly wealthy Chinese looking for bottles with cachet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cabernet isn’t the most obvious pawn in a trade war between the United States and China. Airplanes and their parts are the leading American export to China. Soybeans and wheat grow in Trump country.

articles.headline: Trump Plans to Send National Guard to the Mexican Border
articles.snippet: The White House said Tuesday night that President Trump plans to deploy the National Guard to confront what it called a growing threat of illegal immigrants, drugs and crime from Central America.
articles.abstract: The White House said Tuesday night that President Trump plans to deploy the National Guard to confront what it called a growing threat of illegal immigrants, drugs and crime from Central America.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House said Tuesday night that President Trump planned to deploy the National Guard to the southern border to confront what it called a growing threat of illegal immigrants, drugs and crime from Central America after the president for the third consecutive day warned about the looming dangers of unchecked immigration.

articles.headline: Inside a Private Prison: Blood, Suicide and Poorly Paid Guards
articles.snippet: A trial in Mississippi provides a rare glimpse into a world where mistreatment of inmates is commonplace, at a time when the Trump administration wants to expand the use of private prisons.
articles.abstract: A trial in Mississippi provides a rare glimpse into a world where mistreatment of inmates is commonplace, at a time when the Trump administration wants to expand the use of private prisons.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — On the witness stand and under pressure, Frank Shaw, the warden of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, could not guarantee that the prison was capable of performing its most basic function.

articles.headline: For Tesla, ‘Production Hell’ Looks Like the Reality of the Car Business
articles.snippet: The electric-car maker said output of its first mass-market offering, the Model 3, was up to 2,000 a week. But that’s still short of the goal set by Elon Musk.
articles.abstract: The electric-car maker said output of its first mass-market offering, the Model 3, was up to 2,000 a week. But that’s still short of the goal set by Elon Musk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla began producing electric cars at its plant in Fremont, Calif., six years ago, starting with small quantities and ramping up to about 100,000 vehicles last year. Now, as it tries to double or triple that number, the company and its chief executive, Elon Musk, are getting a lesson in how hard it is to mass-produce automobiles.
